channel.title: Comments on: Why you should publish the shit out of your PhD as early as possible

item.title: By: Mohamed
item.dc:creator: Mohamed
item.description: I am starting my PhD and I really appreciate your thoughts on this. I especially enjoyed your perspective on peer-review as another pair of eyes making sure one's thoughts and ideas are as complete as possible. Thanks a lot for sharing this.
item.content:encoded: I am starting my PhD and I really appreciate your thoughts on this. I especially enjoyed your perspective on peer-review as another pair of eyes making sure one’s thoughts and ideas are as complete as possible. Thanks a lot for sharing this.

item.title: By: Marios
item.dc:creator: Marios
item.description: Totally agree. If the data make sense and you have a mature understanding (or at least a rough understanding) of what is going on, go and publish asap. A paper also gives you the freedom to attend highly-esteem conferences and talk freely about your research without being worrying that others will ste your work. They might get good ideas for further research but you might also gain collaborations which lead to more papers (as a co-author). Also having papers means that the PhD viva will be easy, sweet and enjoyable. Also papers give confidence, and confidence leads to success.
item.content:encoded: Totally agree. If the data make sense and you have a mature understanding (or at least a rough understanding) of what is going on, go and publish asap. A paper also gives you the freedom to attend highly-esteem conferences and talk freely about your research without being worrying that others will ste your work. They might get good ideas for further research but you might also gain collaborations which lead to more papers (as a co-author). Also having papers means that the PhD viva will be easy, sweet and enjoyable. Also papers give confidence, and confidence leads to success.

item.title: By: protohedgehog
item.dc:creator: protohedgehog
item.description:
In reply to <a href="http://fossilsandshit.com/why-you-should-publish-the-shit-out-of-your-phd-as-early-as-possible/#comment-2772">Fran</a>.
The simple answer is, how do we avoid plagiarism - citation! Publish, blog about your work - just make sure that you appropriately cite all sources, including your own, to avoid any conflicts. It's just good scholarship :)
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Fran.

The simple answer is, how do we avoid plagiarism – citation! Publish, blog about your work – just make sure that you appropriately cite all sources, including your own, to avoid any conflicts. It’s just good scholarship üôÇ

item.title: By: Fran
item.dc:creator: Fran
item.description: I was told not to even blog PhD research in case of self-plagiarism, thoughts appreciated!
item.content:encoded: I was told not to even blog PhD research in case of self-plagiarism, thoughts appreciated!

item.title: By: Valja
item.dc:creator: Valja
item.description:
Thank you very much for sharing your experience! Unfortunately, this advise came a bit too late for me, but I am sure it will help many other PhD students.
There are so many things which I wish I had known before I started my PhD. Of course, some mistakes and experiences are inevitable. But so many problems could be avoided, foreseen or simplified by passing on the experience and knowledge of the (almost) graduated PhDs, postdocs and professors to the newbies. In my opinion, this should be the task of the advisor but it seems that this is either not wanted or ignored or forgotten. I have stumbled upon so many good practice guidelines and advises after it was already too late to follow them, because before I was not aware of certain issues and problems.
item.content:encoded:
Thank you very much for sharing your experience! Unfortunately, this advise came a bit too late for me, but I am sure it will help many other PhD students.

There are so many things which I wish I had known before I started my PhD. Of course, some mistakes and experiences are inevitable. But so many problems could be avoided, foreseen or simplified by passing on the experience and knowledge of the (almost) graduated PhDs, postdocs and professors to the newbies. In my opinion, this should be the task of the advisor but it seems that this is either not wanted or ignored or forgotten. I have stumbled upon so many good practice guidelines and advises after it was already too late to follow them, because before I was not aware of certain issues and problems.
